title: HDBSCAN in token-level clouds
text: first step decide lemmas HDBSCAN computed; often might interested medoids. HDBSCAN information, clustering membership probabilities \(\varepsilon\) values, principle included NephoVis, require lot adjusting ’s still wishlist. current workaround leave HDBSCAN visualization Level3 ShinyApp1, requires output step RDS file type-level distance matrices corresponding different models. file named list one item per lemma, lemma senses dataframe token IDs general information interest , importantly, medoidCoords named list one item per model. model object includes: coords: coordinates tokens, next variables “variables” dataframe like, case, “senses”, well tailored list context words. summarizeHDBSCAN() adds HDBSCAN-derived values (cluster, membership \(\varepsilon\)). cws: distribution first-order context words across HDBSCAN clusters t-SNE coordinates available. dataframe one row per context word per cluster recall, precision F-score information relationship context word HDBSCAN cluster. Note , order use tailored contexts, need already computed stored '[lemma].variables.tsv' file shown vignette('weightConcordance'). main function, summarizeHDBSCAN(), requires: lemma input_dir: directory distance matrices stored output_dir: directory output vignette('processClouds') stored coords_name: infix coordinates files can also use purrr::map() create named list gathering full data lemma)
code: # You could run it on all the models or just the medoids # models <- read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, lpaste0(lemma, ".models.tsv")))$`_model` # all models models <- read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".medoids.tsv")))$medoids # only medoids res <- map(setNames(models, models),            summarizeHDBSCAN, lemma = lemma,            input_dir = input_dir,            output_dir = output_dir,            coords_name = '.tsne.30')  # I would normally make one of these files for all my lemmas and store it within the github directory above the lemma subdirectories to_write <- list() to_write[lemma] <- res write_rds(to_write, file.path(output_dir, "hdbscan.rds")) lemmas <- c('lemma1', 'lemma2', 'lemma3') #or whatever they are input_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "output", "tokens") # where the data is stored output_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "nephovis") # where the data will go  # HDBSCAN ---- map(setNames(lemmas, lemmas), function(lemma){   models <- read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".medoids.tsv")))$medoids # only medoids   map(setNames(models, models),       summarizeHDBSCAN, lemma = lemma,       input_dir = file.path(input_dir, lemma),       output_dir = file.path(output_dir, lemma)) }) %>%   write_rds(file.path(output_dir, "hdbscan.rds"))

title: HDBSCAN in token-level clouds
text: Running classifyModel() path distance matrices output summarizeHDBSCAN() returns dataframe one row per model per cluster, summary information related HDBSCAN clustering (\(\varepsilon\) values) mean distances tokens separability indices relation t-SNE rendering. addition, uses variables classify shapes clusters. purrr::imap_dfr() can combine data across multiple lemmas overarching dataframe. Note data correspond whatever went summarizeHDBSCAN(): like classification models, need run summarizeHDBSCAN() .
code: models <- readRDS(file.path(output_dir, "hdbscan.rds")) # output of the previous section  # For one model lname <- names(models)[[1]] mname <- names(models[[lname]]$medoidCoords)[[1]]  classifyModel(models[[lname]]$medoidCoords[[1]],              names(models[[lname]]$medoidCoords)[[1]],              file.path(input_dir, lname))               # For all models, all lemmas classification <- imap_dfr(models, function(ldata, lname){     imap_dfr(models[[lname]]$medoidCoords, classifyModel,     ttmx_dir = file.path(input_dir, lname)) %>%      mutate(lemma = lname) })

title: HDBSCAN in token-level clouds
text: Campello, Ricardo J. G. B., Davoud Moulavi, Joerg Sander. 2013. “Density-Based Clustering Based Hierarchical Density Estimates.” Advances Knowledge Discovery Data Mining, edited Jian Pei, Vincent S. Tseng, Longbing Cao, Hiroshi Motoda, Guandong Xu, 160–72. Lecture Notes Computer Science. Berlin, Heidelberg: Springer. Montes, Mariana. 2021. “Cloudspotting: Visual Analytics Distributional Semantics.” PhD thesis, Leuven: KU Leuven.

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
code: # based on the directory structure resulting from the Python workflow lemma <- 'name_of_lemma' base_dir <- "path/to/data" # shared path input_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "output", "tokens", lemma) # where the data is stored cw_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "output", "cws", lemma) output_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "nephovis", lemma) # where the data will go

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: first step go token-level distance matrices apply dimensionality reduction obtain two coordinates visualization. purpose need decide methods interested (case want compare ). options : 'mds': nonmetric multidimensional scaling (ran vegan::metaMDS()) 'tsne': t-stochastic neighbor embedding (ran Rtsne::Rtsne()), different perplexities indicated appending number label, e.g. 'tsne20', 'tsne30'… 'umap': uniform manifold approximation projection (ran umap::umap()). technique, obtain different solution, results tab-separated file one row per token, column IDs two columns per model: x y coordinates. named list shown inform code techniques use (names list) infixes use file names. example, code line run Rtsne::Rtsne() perplexity 30 store coordinates file called 'name_of_lemma.tsne.30.tsv'. list must also stored, inform NephoVis available visualization options find data. also need list filenames obtain distances , either read filtering contents output_dir appending file extension names models register. getClouds() function groups full “workflow”: sets one empty dataframe per item solutions, filled coordinates stored '[lemma].[solution].tsv' file. file files_list: 2.1 extracts model name 2.2 loads file tokensFromPac() 2.3 logrank = TRUE (default), applies transformation; logdist = TRUE also computes euclidean distances log-transformed values instead just making symmetric. clouds Cloudspotting generated logrank = TRUE, logdist = FALSE. 2.4 applies corresponding algorithm extracts coordinates 2.5 appends coordinates columns preceded name model corresponding dataframe: '[modelname].x'; '[modelname].y'. addition, “mds” one algorithms, return list stress values. can read files readr::read_tsv().
code: # This list works for a loop in the function below and should then be stored as a json file # in the github directory of each lemma, to tell the visualization what is being used solutions_old <- list("mds" = ".mds") for (perp in c(10, 20, 30, 50)) {     solutions_old[[paste0("tsne", perp)]] = paste0(".tsne.", perp) } solutions_old solutions <- list("tsne30" = ".tsne.30") write(rjson::toJSON(solutions), file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".solutions.json"))) suffix <- ".ttmx.dist.pac" models_file <- file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, '.models.tsv')) files_list <- paste0(read_tsv(models_file)$`_model`, suffix) getClouds(input_dir, output_dir, files_list, lemma, solutions) read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".tsne.30.tsv")))

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: context words, workflow exactly tokens. difference files saved '.csv' (reason R read .wwmx...pac) uses focdistsFromCsv() function. indicated specifying type = "focdists".
code: suffix <- ".wwmx.dist.csv" files_list <- paste0(read_tsv(models_file)$`_model`, suffix)  getClouds(cw_dir, output_dir, files_list, lemma, solutions, type = "focdists")

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: files created getClouds() take care visualization Levels 2 3 NephoVis. Level 1 plot, well distance matrix Level 2 selection medoids, first need obtain distances models. purpose, compLemma() loads '[lemma].models.tsv' file output_dir order modify appending coordinates vegan::metaMDS() distances models. default, compute “euclidean” distances transformed matrices (see eucliMats()), function can changed fun argument, transformation can turned transformed argument. returns data register, tend combine across lemmas store euclidean_register.tsv tell index visualization lemmas offer. hood, also stores distance matrix [lemma].models.dist.tsv. file already exists, loads instead recomputing distances. distance matrix used Level 2 NephoVis.
code: reg <- compLemma(lemma, input_dir, output_dir)

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: medoids simply calculated cluster::pam() basic information stored [lemma].medoids.tsv file. important column visualization medoids, NephoVis reads automatically select right models. can also add clustering information models register.
code: k <- 8 # number of medoids you want  distmtx <- read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".models.dist.tsv"))) %>%    matricizeCloud() %>% as.dist() pam_data <- pam(distmtx, k = k) medoid_data <- pam_data$clusinfo %>%   as_tibble() %>%   mutate(medoids = pam_data$medoids, medoid_i = seq(k))  write_tsv(medoid_data, file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".medoids.tsv"))) models_file <- file.path(output_dir, paste0(lemma, ".models.tsv")) read_tsv(models_file) %>%      mutate(         pam_cluster = pam_data$clustering[`_model`], # add pam-cluster number         medoid = pam_data$medoids[pam_cluster] # add name of medoid     ) %>%      write_tsv(models_file)

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: visualization can also take advantage tailored contexts different models; code obtain columns, based output semasioFlow.contextwords.listContextwords() data '[lemma].variables.tsv', described vignette('weightConcordance'). addition, HDBSCAN clustering classification clusters covered vignette('HDBSCAN').

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: code run workflow across multiple lemmas.
code: lemmas <- c('lemma1', 'lemma2', 'lemma3') #or whatever they are base_dir <- '/path/to/data' input_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "output", "tokens") # where the data is stored cw_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "output", "cws") output_dir <- file.path(base_dir, "nephovis") # where the data will go solutions <- list("tsne30" = ".tsne.30")  # Token level ---- suffix <- ".ttmx.dist.pac" for (lemma in lemmas) {   models_file <- file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, '.models.tsv'))   files_list <- paste0(read_tsv(models_file)$`_model`, suffix)   write(toJSON(solutions), file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ".solutions.json")))   getClouds(file.path(input_dir, lemma), file.path(output_dir, lemma), files_list, lemma, solutions) }  # Context words level ----  suffix <- ".wwmx.dist.csv" for (lemma in lemmas) {   models_file <- file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, '.models.tsv'))   files_list <- paste0(read_tsv(models_file)$`_model`, suffix)   getClouds(file.path(cw_dir, lemma), file.path(output_dir, lemma), files_list, lemma, solutions,             type = 'focdists') }  # Distances between models ---- reg <- map_dfr(lemmas, ~compLemma(.x, file.path(input_dir, .x), file.path(output_dir, .x))) write_tsv(reg, file.path(output_dir, "euclidean_register.tsv"))  # Medoids ----  k <- 8 for (lemma in lemmas) {   distmtx <- read_tsv(file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ".models.dist.tsv"))) %>%     matricizeCloud() %>% as.dist()   pam_data <- pam(distmtx, k = k)   medoid_data <- pam_data$clusinfo %>%     as_tibble() %>%     mutate(medoids = pam_data$medoids, medoid_i = seq(k))      write_tsv(medoid_data, file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ".medoids.tsv")))      models_file <- file.path(output_dir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ".models.tsv"))   read_tsv(models_file) %>%     mutate(       pam_cluster = pam_data$clustering[`_model`], # add pam-cluster number       medoid = pam_data$medoids[pam_cluster] # add name of medoid       ) %>%     write_tsv(models_file) }

title: From semasioFlow to NephoVis
text: Montes, Mariana. 2021. “Cloudspotting: Visual Analytics Distributional Semantics.” PhD thesis, Leuven: KU Leuven. Montes, Mariana, Karlien Franco, Kris Heylen. 2021. “Indestructible Insights. Case Study Distributional Prototype Semantics.” Cognitive Sociolinguistics Revisited, edited Gitte Kristiansen, Karlien Franco, Stefano De Pascale, Laura Rosseel, Weiwei Zhang, 251–63. De Gruyter. https://doi.org/10.1515/9783110733945-021.

title: Weight contexts
text: context-weighting procedure assumes following datasets produced semasioFlow (Python): dataframe one row per context word columns frequency weight information (importantly, column weight use first-order filtering/weighting). context word ID column called 'cw'. file typically called '[lemma].ppmi.tsv' stored nephovis data (.e. output_dir vignette('processClouds'). created semasioFlow.socmodels.targetPPMI(). dataframe one row per context word per token, corpus-based information. generated semasioFlow.contextwords.listContextwords() least : cw column type context word target_lemma column type target word column word form token_id cw_id columns distance context word target similar computed values. typically called '[lemma].cws.detail.tsv'. dataframe one row per token columns annotation values variables, well columns semicolon-separated context words. token ID column called _id context word columns start _cws. followed (first part ) name model. Crucially, possible parse relevant parameter settings name model. file typically called '[lemma].variables.tsv' stored nephovis data (.e. output_dir vignette('processClouds'). ‘token_register’ element list returned semasioFlow.socmodels.weightTokens() also include manually added variables. first second dataframes loaded merged setupConcordancer(), order add weighting information token-based register. pmi_columnname function identifies name column weighting information (default 'pmi_4') renames myweight. two ways point files function. names correspond naming convention stored directory nephodir, can run setupConcordancer(lemma, nephodir). Otherwise, can use setupConcordancer(cws_detail_path = 'path//cws.detail.tsv', ppmi_path = 'path//ppmi.tsv'). third dataframe loaded separately.
code: cws <- setupConcordancer(cws_detail_path = file.path(cws_detail_dir, paste0(lemma, '.cws.detail.tsv')),                          ppmi_path = file.path(nephodir, lemma, paste0(lemma, '.ppmi.tsv'))) variables <- readr::read_tsv(file.path(nephodir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ('.variables.tsv'))),                             show_col_types = F, quote = "")

title: Weight contexts
text: main function, weightConcordance(), takes dataframes name lemma1 input returns enriched version variables dataframe raw context _ctxt.raw column tailored contexts columns starting _ctxt., followed (first part ) name model. tailored context wraps target token words captured model HTML tags read visualization tools: target wrapped <span> tags class = "target", NephoVis reads bold coloured based colour dot token connected .2 Context words captured model token wrapped <strong> tags thus rendered bold. also possible add weight superscript.
code: ctxts <- weightConcordance(variables, cws, lemma) write_tsv(ctxts, file.path(nephodir, lemma, paste0(lemma, ('.variables.tsv'))), escape = 'none')

title: Weight contexts
text: default settings functions assume certain pattern names columns extract parameter settings , can adapted various optional arguments. allow user customize (1) read model name, (2) translate names parameters selections context words (3) corpus-related issues.

title: Weight contexts
text: default model name created semasioFlow made two strings joined period (e.g. 'bound5-5lex.PPMIweight'): first encodes first-order selection parameters (e.g. 'bound5-5lex') second, weighting information (e.g. 'PPMIweight'). information encoded way model names, can adjust foc_param_fun weight_param_fun arguments (see ?weightLemma). foc_param_fun function takes name model returns string first-order filters. default function(m) stringr::str_split(m, '\\.')[[1]][[1]]: first element .-separated sequence. weight_param_fun function takes name model returns string weighting filters. default function(m) stringr::str_split(m, '\\.')[[1]][[2]]: second element .-separated sequence. sup_weight_fun function takes string weighting information read function weight_param_fun (e.g. 'PPMIweight') returns boolean value indicating whether PPMI values included superindices tailored concordance. See ?weightLemma. default function(weightparam) stringr::str_ends(weightparam, 'weight'): context words weighted weighting parameter ends 'weight'. wanted PPMI values always included next captured context words, run weightConcordance(variables, cws, lemma, sup_weight_fun = function(x) return(TRUE)).

title: Weight contexts
text: default values interpreting parameter settings tailored corpus setting used Montes (2021). want instruct function read parameter settings instead. See ?filterWeight ?filterFoc. descriptions, foc_param refers first-order information read function foc_param_fun (e.g. 'bound5-5lex' weight_param weighting information read function weight_param_fun (e.g. 'PPMIweight'). instructions used identify context words captured model token; addition, semicolon-separated list context words original file also used. is_dep_fun max_steps_fun Functions take foc_param returns TRUE dependency information collected (former) number steps dependency path accept viable context words (latter). default value is_dep_fun function(foc_param) stringr::str_starts(foc_param, 'LEMMA'): dependency information used string starts 'LEMMA'. default value max_steps_fun function(foc_param) (foc_param == 'LEMMAPATH2') 2 else 3, means restricts steps LEMMAPATH2 models 3 otherwise. relevant result is_dep_fun TRUE. window_filter_fun Function takes foc_param returns vector list two elements, viz. left right window spans. used result is_dep_fun FALSE. default value windowFilter() shown : extracts digits separated hyphen reads left right span respectively. used one digit, e.g. '5' refer windows, use something like function(x) stringr::str_replace(x, '[^\\d]+([\\d]+)[^\\d]+', '\\1-\\1'). pos_filter_fun Function takes foc_param returns vector; empty, filter implemented, values, rows column pos matches element list included. used result is_dep_fun FALSE. default value posFilter() shown : foc_param ends 'lex', context words 'noun', 'adj', 'adv' 'verb' pos considered captured; otherwise, . 'lex' ending means something else data, can replace function customized version used list parts speech filter. name parameter setting different, even multiple possibilities, can adapt function requirements well. bound_filter_fun Function takes foc_param returns TRUE words outside sentence also captured FALSE excluded. default function (foc_param) stringr::str_starts(foc_param, 'nobound'): words outside sentence accepted foc_param starts 'nobound'. parameter vary models even recorded model name, use function function(x) return TRUE. weight_filter_fun threshold former function takes weight_param returns TRUE weighting included FALSE ignored. Including weighting implies values myweight column (defined setupConcordance()) used filter context words. threshold arguments sets value used filtering context words based myweight output weight_filter_fun TRUE. default function(weightparam) stringr::str_ends(weightparam, '', negate = TRUE): returns FALSE weighting parameter ends ''. default threshold 0.
code: windowFilter <- function(foc_param) {   windows <- foc_param %>%     stringr::str_extract('\\d+-\\d+') %>%     stringr::str_split('-')   readr::parse_integer(windows[[1]]) } posFilter <- function(foc_param) {   if (stringr::str_ends(foc_param, 'lex')) {     c('noun', 'adj', 'adv', 'verb')   } else {     c()   } }

' start new sentences new lines. addition, to_remove argument vector strings matching word values ignored. default value c(''), meaning rows value word column removed start.

title: Create token-level clouds
text: Instructions go workflow can found handful vignettes, available Articles section calling vignette(): vignette('processClouds') explains steps output semasioFlow input NephoVis; vignette('weightConcordance') shows create tailored contexts Nephovis; vignette('HDBSCAN') shows implement HDBSCAN clustering models use output classify clouds (clusters). build vignettes installing GitHub run:
code: remotes::install_github("montesmariana/semcloud", build_vignettes = T)

what: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
text: function takes square matrix dmx contains item item distances, factor classes (many items rows, thus columns, dmx) assigns class item. function returns measure q well distances dmx 'capture' classification classes, distances taken  'capture classification' extent items (immediately) surrounded items class, items class. Next overall cluster quality data taken together, function also returns cluster quality individual points  cluster quality individual classes (well mean cluster quality classes). measures called q output function.

title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
code: separationkNN(dmx, classes, k = NULL, weights = c("linear", "s-curve", "none"))

title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
text: dmx square matrix containing item item distances classes factor length number rows columns dmx; class position classes class assigned item row column dmx k value k used identify k nearest neighbours. k specified, k taken either total number items divided ten (number items divided ten smaller size smallest class), size smallest class minus one (size smallest class minus one smaller total number items divided ten). default behaviour obviously crude attempt guessing sensible value k. time probably want overrule default behaviour. explicitly specify k, value one total number items minus one allowed. weights weights argument determines exactly cluster quality point derived class membership k nearest neighbours. cluster quality 'weighted mean class membership values neighbours (1=class target item; 0=different class)', weights determined weights argument. weights k numbers, first indicates weight closest neighbour, second indicates weight second closest neighbour, etc. sum weights always one. weights "linear", default situation, weights decrease linearly one progresses set neighbours (starting one closest target item). weights "s-curve", weights decrease one progresses set neigbours (starting one closest target item) according s-shape y<-(40:-40)/10; plot(1:81, exp(y) / (1 + exp(y)), type="l"), actual weights rescaled add one. Finally, weight "none", connections path equal weight. actual weights used call separationkNN() can found weights components output.

title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
text: object class clustqualkNN, list containing least following components: globqual global cluster quality q meanclassqual mean class-specific cluster quality values q classqual table class class-specific clusters quality q pointqual numeric vector item item-specific cluster quality q weights numeric vector weights used k number indication k used

title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
text: q measures calculated follows: first, item item-specific cluster quality calculated. done calculating proportion 'class items' among k nearest neighbours. higher measure, better cluster quality item. However, calculated simply proportion, rather weighted mean values k nearest neighbours, 'class neighbour' value one, 'different class neighbour' value zero, weights neighbours can different settings (see ). default settings, weights decrease linearly rank 'distance item', weights add one. instance, k one weight 1. k 2, weights, starting closest nearest neighbour, .67 .33. k 3, weights .5, .33, .17. k 4, .4, .3, .2, .1. Etc. overall cluster quality data calculated mean cluster quality items. Additionally, cluster quality every class classes calculated mean cluster quality items belonging class. mean class quality, finally, mean class-specific class quality measures.

title: Proportion of same-class nearest neighbours — separationkNN
code: # we create a 'point cloud', with points belonging to two classes points <- rbind(matrix(rnorm(100, 2, 2), ncol=2),                 matrix(rnorm(100, 4, 2), ncol=2))                 dst <- dist(points, diag=TRUE, upper=TRUE)                 classes <- as.factor(rep(c("a","b"), c(50, 50))) # we analyse the cluster quality, letting the procedure choose k fitkNN <- separationkNN(dst, classes) summary(fitkNN) #>               Length Class  Mode    #> classfreqs      2    table  numeric #> classqual       2    -none- numeric #> pointclass    100    factor numeric #> pointqual     100    -none- numeric #> globqual        1    -none- numeric #> meanclassqual   1    -none- numeric #> k               1    -none- numeric #> weights        10    -none- numeric fitkNN$globqual        # global cluster quality #> [1] 0.6438182 fitkNN$meanclassqual   # mean class quality #> [1] 0.6438182 fitkNN$classqual       # class-specific quality #>         a         b  #> 0.6574545 0.6301818   # we analyse the cluster quality, setting k to 25 fitkNN <- separationkNN(dst, classes, k=25) summary(fitkNN) #>               Length Class  Mode    #> classfreqs      2    table  numeric #> classqual       2    -none- numeric #> pointclass    100    factor numeric #> pointqual     100    -none- numeric #> globqual        1    -none- numeric #> meanclassqual   1    -none- numeric #> k               1    -none- numeric #> weights        25    -none- numeric

title: Set up Concordancer — setupConcordancer
text: Prepare dataframes getContext.

title: Set up Concordancer — setupConcordancer
code: setupConcordancer(   lemma = "",   input_dir = "",   cws_detail_path = file.path(input_dir, paste0(lemma, ".cws.detail.tsv")),   ppmi_path = file.path(input_dir, paste0(lemma, ".ppmi.tsv")),   pmi_columnname = "pmi_4",   distance_corrector_func = function(word) !stringr::str_starts(word, "<"),   lemma_from_tid_fun = function(tid) paste(stringr::str_split(tid, "/")[[1]][-c(3, 4)],     collapse = "/") )

title: Set up Concordancer — setupConcordancer
text: lemma Name lemma: default filenames input_dir Directory files stored cws_detail_path Path dataframe one row per context word per token context words information token. Created listContextWords semasioFlow Python module. ppmi_path Path dataframe one context word per row frequency information pmi_columnname Name (prefix) column dataframe found ppmi_path weighting values stored. distance_corrector_func Function filter rows dataframe cws_detail_path based values word column, recalculate distances words. lemma_from_tid_fun Function extract target lemma tokenID.

title: Set up Concordancer — setupConcordancer
text: Enriched dataframe one row per context word per token, weight values, corrected distances column indicating right target lemma (case one).

title: Summarize HDBSCAN data for a model — summarizeHDBSCAN

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: sym() creates symbol string syms() creates list symbols character vector. enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. enquo() returns single quoted expression, like blueprint delayed computation. enquos() returns list quoted expressions. expr() quotes new expression locally. mostly useful build new expressions around arguments captured enquo() enquos(): expr(mean(!!enquo(arg), na.rm = TRUE)). as_name() transforms quoted variable name string. Supplying something else quoted variable name error. unlike as_label() also returns single string supports kind R object input, including quoted function calls vectors. purpose summarise object single label. label often suitable default name. know quoted expression contains (instance expressions captured enquo() variable name, call function, unquoted constant), use as_label(). know quoted simple variable name, like enforce , use as_name(). learn tidy eval use tools, visit https://tidyeval.tidyverse.org Metaprogramming section Advanced R.

title: Create weighted concordance lines — weightConcordance

title: Create weighted concordance lines — weightConcordance
text: variables Dataframe one row per token ID least columns prefixed _cws. semicolon-separated context words. cws Dataframe one row per token ID per context word outputted setupConcordancer. lemma Name lemma, process model names ... Arguments passed weightLemma getContext, order adapt different ways coding parameter settings. See vignette('weightConcordance').

title: Create weighted concordance lines — weightConcordance
text: Enriched variables dataframe columns containing weighted concordance lines.

title: Create weighted concordance lines — weightConcordance
code: if (FALSE) { cws <- setupConcordancer(lemma, input_dir) variables <- readr::read_tsv('path/to/file', lazy = F) ctxts <- weightConcordance(variables, cws, lemma) }
